definitions: covered with a veil or similar covering that partially hides or obscures
expressed indirectly or in a disguised manner to conceal true meaning or intention
examples: The veiled woman walked through the market quietly
Her face remained veiled during the entire ceremony
He made a veiled threat about revealing secrets
The veiled criticism in her speech was still obvious

definitions: having visible veins, streaks, or branching lines resembling blood vessels running through
examples: The veined marble countertop looked elegant and expensive
Her veined hands showed her advanced age clearly
The veined leaves displayed intricate patterns beneath sunlight
This veined cheese has a distinctive strong flavor

definitions: having the soft, smooth texture characteristic of velvet fabric
examples: The velvet petals felt luxurious against her skin
His velvet voice soothed everyone in the room
The velvet darkness of night enveloped the city
She stroked the cat's velvet fur gently

definitions: having a soft, smooth texture resembling velvet in feel or appearance
examples: The velvety chocolate mousse melted on her tongue
His velvety skin felt incredibly smooth to touch
The wine had a velvety finish that lingered
She loved the velvety texture of the fabric

definitions: commanding respect because of great age, dignity, character, or position in society
examples: The venerable professor had taught for fifty years
They visited the venerable cathedral built centuries ago
The venerable judge commanded respect in the courtroom
This venerable institution has served the community well

definitions: desiring or seeking revenge; wanting to retaliate for perceived wrongs or injuries
examples: The vengeful warrior pursued his enemies relentlessly everywhere
Her vengeful attitude destroyed many important personal relationships
He wrote a vengeful letter after being fired
The vengeful spirit haunted those who wronged her

definitions: producing or secreting venom; capable of injecting poison through bite or sting
full of bitter malice, spite, or extreme hostility in manner or speech
examples: The venomous snake struck quickly at its prey
Several venomous spiders live in this tropical region
Her venomous remarks hurt everyone at the meeting
He responded with venomous criticism of their work

definitions: provided with openings or outlets for air, gas, or liquid to pass through
examples: The vented helmet kept the rider cool effectively
This vented container prevents dangerous pressure buildup inside
The vented attic space improved home energy efficiency
She wore vented shoes for better air circulation

definitions: provided with fresh air circulation through natural or mechanical means for comfort
examples: The well ventilated room felt comfortable despite summer heat
This ventilated storage area prevents mold growth effectively
The ventilated greenhouse maintained ideal growing conditions year-round
Workers need properly ventilated spaces for safety reasons

definitions: using exactly the same words; repeated or copied word for word without change
examples: She repeated his instructions verbatim to avoid mistakes
The verbatim transcript captured every word spoken precisely
He quoted the passage verbatim from the original
The verbatim record proved crucial in the trial

definitions: using more words than necessary; characterized by wordiness and unnecessary elaboration in expression
examples: His verbose writing style made reports difficult reading
The verbose speaker lost the audience's attention quickly
She gave a verbose explanation of simple concepts
The verbose manual confused more than it helped

definitions: green with grass or other rich vegetation; covered in fresh, lush plant growth
examples: The verdant meadow stretched endlessly before the hikers
Spring rains created verdant hillsides throughout the region
They picnicked in a verdant valley beside streams
The verdant garden required constant watering and care

definitions: able to be checked, confirmed, or proven true through evidence or investigation
examples: All claims must be verifiable through reliable sources
The scientist provided verifiable data supporting her theory
His employment history was easily verifiable by records
They required verifiable proof of income for loans

definitions: confirmed, proven, or established as true, accurate, or legitimate through checking
examples: The verified account belonged to the celebrity herself
All verified facts were included in the report
She used only verified sources for her research
The verified results confirmed their initial hypothesis completely

definitions: in the process of checking, confirming, or establishing the truth or accuracy
examples: The bank is verifying your account information now
Scientists are verifying the experimental results through repetition
She spent hours verifying data for the project
The verifying process takes several business days typically

definitions: being truly or very much so; genuine, actual, or real without exaggeration
examples: The sale created a veritable stampede of shoppers
Her garden was a veritable paradise of colors
He faced a veritable mountain of paperwork daily
The storm brought a veritable deluge of rain

definitions: of a vivid red to reddish-orange color like the pigment mercuric sulfide
examples: The vermilion sunset painted the sky dramatically tonight
She wore vermilion lipstick to the formal event
The artist mixed vermilion paint for the flowers
Vermilion robes distinguished the high-ranking monks clearly

definitions: using the native language or dialect of a particular country, region, or group
examples: He wrote poetry in vernacular English, avoiding formality
The vernacular architecture reflected local building traditions perfectly
Medical terms were explained in vernacular language clearly
She studied vernacular expressions from different regions extensively

definitions: able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions, activities, or situations
examples: The versatile actor played both comedy and drama
This versatile tool serves multiple purposes around homes
She's a versatile athlete excelling in several sports
The versatile ingredient works in sweet or savory

definitions: experienced, practiced, or skilled in a particular subject or activity through study
examples: She's well versed in classical literature and poetry
The lawyer was versed in international trade law
He's versed in multiple programming languages and frameworks
The versed musician played several instruments professionally well

definitions: having a backbone or spinal column; belonging to the subphylum of animals with backbones
examples: Vertebrate animals include mammals, birds, and reptiles
The vertebrate fossil showed clear spinal structure remains
Scientists study vertebrate evolution through comparative anatomy research
All vertebrate species share certain developmental characteristics fundamentally

definitions: at right angles to the horizontal plane; upright, straight up and down
examples: The vertical cliff face challenged even experienced climbers
She drew vertical lines to divide the page
The vertical garden maximized limited urban space efficiently
Vertical blinds filtered the bright morning sunlight effectively

definitions: having a legal right or claim that cannot be taken away or denied
wearing or dressed in a vest or similar garment over other clothing
examples: Employees have vested rights to their pension benefits
She has vested interest in the company's success
The vested choir members sang during Sunday service
Vested security guards patrolled the building premises regularly

definitions: remaining as a trace or remnant of something that was once larger or more developed
examples: The whale's vestigial leg bones prove evolutionary history
Some snakes retain vestigial hip bones from ancestors
The vestigial organ no longer serves any function
These vestigial structures provide evidence of common ancestry

definitions: relating to the medical care and treatment of animals, especially domestic animals
examples: The veterinary clinic treated pets and farm animals
She studied veterinary medicine at the state university
Veterinary care has advanced significantly in recent decades
The veterinary surgeon operated on the injured dog

definitions: feeling or showing annoyance, frustration, or worry about something difficult or troubling
examples: She looked vexed by the constant interruptions today
The vexed customer demanded to speak with management
He felt vexed about the unresolved problem situation
The vexed expression revealed her growing impatience clearly

definitions: full of energy, enthusiasm, and life; pulsating with vigor or activity
bright, striking, and intense in color or light; vivid and eye-catching
examples: The vibrant community celebrated its cultural diversity proudly
She has a vibrant personality that attracts people
The artist used vibrant colors throughout the painting
The vibrant sunset lit up the evening sky

definitions: relating to or characterized by vibration or rapid back-and-forth movement of particles
examples: The vibrational frequency determines the sound's pitch clearly
Scientists measured vibrational energy in the molecular structure
Vibrational therapy uses sound waves for healing purposes
The vibrational patterns revealed structural weaknesses in materials

definitions: experienced through imaginative or sympathetic participation in the experience of another person
examples: Parents often feel vicarious pride in children's achievements
She lived vicarious adventures through travel books daily
The audience felt vicarious embarrassment for the performer
He gained vicarious pleasure from his friend's success

definitions: deliberately cruel or violent; showing a desire to hurt or harm others
severe, intense, or harsh in degree, manner, or effect on someone
examples: The vicious attack left several people seriously injured
She spread vicious rumors about her former friend
The vicious storm destroyed homes throughout the region
They faced vicious competition in the global market

definitions: made to suffer unfairly; singled out for cruel or unjust treatment by others
examples: The victimized students reported bullying to school authorities
She felt victimized by the unfair company policies
Victimized communities struggled to rebuild after the disaster
The victimized witness needed protection from further harm

definitions: relating to the reign of Queen Victoria or the attitudes and values of that period
having attitudes of strict morality and propriety associated with the Victorian period
examples: The Victorian mansion featured ornate architectural details throughout
She collected Victorian furniture and decorative arts pieces
His Victorian attitudes about relationships seemed outdated now
The Victorian sensibilities prohibited discussing certain topics openly

definitions: having won a victory or success; triumphant in battle, competition, or conflict
examples: The victorious team celebrated their championship win enthusiastically
She emerged victorious from the difficult legal battle
The victorious army returned home to cheering crowds
His victorious smile showed pride in the achievement

definitions: able to be looked at, watched, or seen; suitable or available for viewing
examples: The documents are viewable online through secure access
These files are viewable only with special software
The eclipse was viewable from several countries simultaneously
The viewable area increased with the larger screen

definitions: keeping careful watch for possible danger or difficulties; alert and attentive constantly
examples: The vigilant guard noticed suspicious activity immediately nearby
Parents must remain vigilant about online safety always
Vigilant citizens reported the unusual behavior to police
She stayed vigilant during the long night shift

definitions: strong, healthy, and full of energy; characterized by forceful and energetic action
examples: The vigorous exercise routine improved his fitness significantly
She gave a vigorous defense of her position
The plant showed vigorous growth in spring sunshine
They engaged in vigorous debate about the issue

definitions: extremely unpleasant to the senses or feelings; disgusting or offensive
morally despicable, wicked, or shameful; deserving strong condemnation or disgust
examples: The vile smell from the garbage made everyone sick
He made vile comments about his former colleagues
The vile weather ruined our outdoor wedding plans
Such vile behavior will not be tolerated here

definitions: relating to, constituting, or befitting a villain; extremely wicked or criminal in nature
examples: His villainous plot to steal the fortune failed
The actor perfected his villainous laugh for movies
The villainous scheme involved betraying trusted friends completely
She played villainous characters in several thriller films

definitions: cleared of accusation, blame, or suspicion; shown to be right or justified
examples: The vindicated defendant celebrated after years of trials
Her vindicated theory earned recognition from fellow scientists
He felt vindicated when evidence proved his innocence
The vindicated whistleblower received public apology finally

definitions: having or showing a strong desire for revenge; pursuing retaliation beyond reasonable measure
examples: Her vindictive behavior destroyed several professional relationships permanently
The vindictive lawsuit seemed motivated by personal grudges
He made vindictive comments about former business partners
The vindictive response exceeded the original offense greatly

definitions: broken, infringed, or disregarded, especially referring to rules, agreements, or personal boundaries
examples: The violated treaty led to renewed military conflict
She felt violated by the invasion of privacy
The violated regulations resulted in heavy financial penalties
His violated trust could never be fully restored

definitions: of a bluish-purple color seen at the end of the spectrum opposite red
examples: She wore a beautiful violet dress to the gala
The violet flowers bloomed in early spring gardens
The sunset sky turned violet before fading to black
He painted the room in soft violet tones

definitions: caused by or relating to a virus or viral infection in living organisms
spreading rapidly and widely through internet sharing, especially on social media platforms
examples: The viral infection spread through the entire school
Doctors prescribed medication for her viral pneumonia symptoms
The video went viral within hours of posting
His viral tweet generated millions of views overnight

definitions: not yet touched, used, or exploited; in original or natural state
having had no sexual intercourse; maintaining a state of sexual inexperience
examples: They explored virgin forest untouched by human development
The virgin snow showed no footprints or tracks
The virgin bride wore traditional white wedding attire
Ancient cultures valued virgin priestesses for temple service

definitions: being in a state of virginity; characterized by purity, innocence, or freshness
examples: The virginal white dress symbolized purity and innocence
Her virginal appearance belied her worldly experience completely
The virginal landscape remained untouched by modern development
He maintained a virginal reputation throughout his career

definitions: having strength, energy, and other qualities traditionally associated with masculine vigor and potency
examples: The virile athlete dominated every competition he entered
His virile appearance attracted attention at the gym
The actor cultivated a virile image for action movies
Ancient statues depicted virile gods with muscular physiques

definitions: showing exceptional skill, especially in music or another artistic pursuit requiring technical mastery
examples: Her virtuoso performance earned standing ovation from audiences
The virtuoso pianist played the complex piece effortlessly
His virtuoso guitar solo impressed even seasoned musicians
The chef's virtuoso knife skills amazed restaurant patrons

definitions: having or showing high moral standards, righteousness, and excellence of character or conduct
examples: The virtuous leader refused all bribes and corruption
She lived a virtuous life dedicated to helping others
His virtuous behavior earned respect from the community
The virtuous choice required personal sacrifice but felt right

definitions: extremely severe or harmful in effects; highly infectious, malignant, or poisonous
bitterly hostile, antagonistic, or harsh in tone, manner, or effect
examples: The virulent strain of flu spread rapidly worldwide
Scientists studied the virulent bacteria under strict containment
His virulent criticism destroyed her confidence completely
The virulent political rhetoric divided the nation deeply

definitions: relating to deep inward feelings rather than intellect; instinctive, emotional, and unreasoned
examples: She had a visceral reaction to the disturbing images
His visceral fear of heights prevented mountain climbing
The movie provoked visceral responses from sensitive viewers
Her visceral hatred of injustice motivated lifelong activism
